contents.title: ## Introduction
contents.text:
This report summarizes the results of public input, encompassing:
 * __54 statements__
 * __2,336 votes__
 * 4 topics
 * 11 subtopics

All voters were anonymous.

contents.title: ## Overview
contents.text:
Below is a high level overview of the topics discussed in the conversation, as well as the percentage of statements categorized under each topic. Note that the percentages may add up to greater than 100% when statements fall under more than one topic.

* **Economic Impact (59%):** The conversation explored the potential effects of policy changes on economic growth, consumer spending, and business profits, with some statements suggesting increased wages could stimulate the economy while others expressed concern about unintended negative consequences and proposed alternative solutions.
* **Minimum Wage (30%):**  Statements in this topic centered on the concept of a living wage, its potential impact on small businesses, and its role in addressing income inequality, with some advocating for specific minimum wage levels while others discussed the potential for job displacement and automation.
* **Small Business (15%):** This topic focused on the challenges small businesses face due to rising labor costs, including the potential for business closures and the need for operational adaptations, with some statements highlighting the disproportionate impact on small businesses compared to larger corporations.
* **Automation (7%):** The conversation touched on the increasing presence of automation in the workforce, its potential link to rising minimum wages, and its long-term consequences, including decreased demand for human workers and the possibility of unionizing automated workers.

contents.title: ## Top 5 Most Discussed Subtopics
contents.text: 11 subtopics of discussion emerged. These 5 subtopics had the most statements submitted.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
* Economic boost from increased spending
* Unintended consequences
* Systemic problems require systemic solutions
* Policy effectiveness
* Alternative implementations like subsidies

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
* Minimum wage inadequacy
* Living wage as a right
* Impact of inflation
* Business responsibility
* Potential trade-offs

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
* Unaffordable wage increases for small businesses
* Disproportionate impact on small businesses
* Job losses/business closures
* Automation/robotics as alternative
* Reduced small business competitiveness

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
* Reduced labor costs
* Small business vulnerability
* Increased operational efficiency
* Owner-operated businesses
* Adapting to higher wages

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
* Increased consumer spending
* Inflationary pressures
* Wage increases
* Reduced consumer spending
* Economic impact

contents.title: ## Topics
contents.text: From the statements submitted, 4 high level topics were identified, as well as 11 subtopics. Based on voting patterns both points of common ground as well as differences of opinion have been identified and are described below.

subContents.title: ### Economic Impact (32 statements)
subContents.text: This topic included 3 subtopics, comprising a total of 32 statements.

subContents.title: #### Overall Economic Growth (27 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had moderately low alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
* **Economic Boost from Increased Wages**: Some statements suggest that increased wages would stimulate the economy by boosting consumer spending.
* **Unintended Consequences**: Some statements express concern about the potential for complex and unforeseen negative consequences.
* **Alternative Solutions**: Some statements propose alternative approaches, such as subsidies, instead of the discussed policy.
* **Systemic Issues**: Some statements argue that the policy addresses symptoms rather than underlying systemic problems.
* **General Confusion**: Several statements express confusion or lack of understanding regarding the discussed policy.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: A participant believes this is transformative but also expresses concern about the unforeseen and complex consequences, even for experienced restaurant professionals.

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a significant difference of opinion (at least 20 votes, and both an agreement rate and disagree rate between 40%% and 60%%).

subContents.title: #### Consumer Spending (4 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had moderately low alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
* **Impact of Increased Wages on Consumer Spending**: Some statements express concern that higher wages will lead to increased prices, causing consumers to reduce spending, while others argue that increased wages will boost the economy by enabling greater consumer spending.
* **Inflationary Concerns**:  One statement suggests that a $15 minimum wage will lead to inflation, penalizing higher-income individuals.
* **Minimum Wage and Affordability**: One statement raises concerns about customers having to pay more to accommodate increased wages and potentially reducing their spending.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a point of common ground (at least 20 votes, and at least 70% agreement).

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a significant difference of opinion (at least 20 votes, and both an agreement rate and disagree rate between 40%% and 60%%).

subContents.title: #### Business Profits (2 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had moderately low alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
* **Profit Reduction as a Potential Outcome**: Some statements suggest the possibility of companies experiencing lower profits.
* **Impact of High Prices on Employment**:  One statement expresses concern about high prices leading to job losses for vulnerable individuals.
* **Price Increases and Market Competition**: One statement considers it unlikely that companies will raise prices due to competitive market pressures.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a point of common ground (at least 20 votes, and at least 70% agreement).

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a significant difference of opinion (at least 20 votes, and both an agreement rate and disagree rate between 40%% and 60%%).

subContents.title: ### Minimum Wage (16 statements)
subContents.text: This topic included 3 subtopics, comprising a total of 16 statements.

subContents.title: #### Living Wage (9 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had high alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
* **Ethical Imperative of a Living Wage**: Some statements argue that providing a living wage is a moral necessity, as current minimum wages are insufficient to cover basic living expenses.
* **Economic Impacts of a Living Wage**: Some statements discuss the economic implications of a living wage, including the potential need for repeated adjustments due to inflation and the impact on businesses.
* **Support for Specific Wage Levels**: Several statements advocate for specific minimum wage amounts, ranging from $15 to $25 per hour.
* **Focus on Low-Wage Workers**: One statement highlights the demographics of minimum wage earners, noting that a majority are adults, to support the argument for a living wage.
* **Alternative Approaches to Income Support**:  One statement suggests replacing existing social programs with a guaranteed minimum income.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: Participants argue that the current minimum wage is insufficient for covering basic living expenses, such as rent and bills.  One participant suggests that workers must advocate for their needs to combat the erosion of their purchasing power due to inflation.  They also propose revisiting relevant laws periodically to ensure economic fairness for low-income families. Another participant asserts that the concept of a "living wage" is ethically unambiguous and that the current minimum wage falls short of this standard.

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a significant difference of opinion (at least 20 votes, and both an agreement rate and disagree rate between 40%% and 60%%).

subContents.title: #### Impact on Small Businesses (5 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had moderately high alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
* **Minimum Wage Increase Impact on Small Businesses**: Several statements express concern that increases in minimum wage disproportionately burden small businesses due to their limited financial capacity, potentially leading to business closures or reduced owner income.
* **Automation as a Response to Wage Increases**: One statement suggests that increased minimum wage may incentivize businesses to adopt automation, potentially leading to job displacement.
* **Unionization in the Context of Automation**: The same statement also proposes that this automation might lead to increased unionization of the remaining workforce.
* **Corporate versus Small Business Impact**: One statement argues that large corporations are better equipped to handle minimum wage increases than small businesses, potentially creating an uneven playing field.
* **Disagreement with the "Anti-Corporate Greed" Narrative**: One statement challenges the framing of minimum wage increases as solely targeting corporate greed, suggesting that small business owners also face financial constraints.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: A participant argued that increases to minimum wage disproportionately affect small businesses, and the law does not adequately address this impact, despite arguments that such increases combat corporate greed.

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a significant difference of opinion (at least 20 votes, and both an agreement rate and disagree rate between 40%% and 60%%).

subContents.title: #### Wage Inequality (2 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had high alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
* **Minimum Wage and Inflation**: Some statements suggest a minimum wage increase will cause inflation, disproportionately affecting higher earners.
* **Income Inequality as a Problem**: Some statements assert the need to address income inequality, viewing a minimum wage increase as a potential, albeit imperfect, solution.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: A participant suggested that a specific proposal is a reasonable, though flawed, first step toward addressing income inequality.

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a significant difference of opinion (at least 20 votes, and both an agreement rate and disagree rate between 40%% and 60%%).

subContents.title: ### Small Business (8 statements)
subContents.text: This topic included 2 subtopics, comprising a total of 8 statements.

subContents.title: #### Business Survival (5 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had moderately low alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
* **Labor Costs and Business Survival**:  Statements suggest that increased labor costs pose a significant challenge to the survival of small businesses, potentially requiring owners to work more and reduce reliance on paid employees.
* **Business Closures**: Some statements predict the closure of small businesses due to economic pressures, including higher wages.
* **Operational Adaptations**: One statement proposes that new businesses might adopt counter-service models to reduce labor costs.
* **Competition and Survival of the Fittest**:  One statement suggests that only the "super strong" businesses, with owners willing to work extensively, will survive in the current economic climate.
* **Impact on Small Businesses**: Statements express concern about the disproportionate impact of economic pressures on small businesses, such as "mom and pop" shops, potentially leading to their disappearance.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a point of common ground (at least 20 votes, and at least 70% agreement).

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a significant difference of opinion (at least 20 votes, and both an agreement rate and disagree rate between 40%% and 60%%).

subContents.title: #### Impact On Small Businesses (3 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had high alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
* **Minimum Wage Increase Impact on Small Business Owners**: The statements express concern that increasing the minimum wage will disproportionately burden small businesses and their owners, who may already be struggling financially.
* **Minimum Wage's Disproportionate Impact on Small vs. Large Businesses**: The statements suggest that large corporations are better equipped to handle minimum wage increases than small businesses.
* **Perceived Ineffectiveness of Minimum Wage Law Provisions**:  The statements indicate a belief that current legal provisions do not adequately address the challenges small businesses face regarding minimum wage increases.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: A participant argued that increases to minimum wage disproportionately affect small businesses, and the law does not adequately address this impact, despite arguments that such increases combat corporate greed.

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a significant difference of opinion (at least 20 votes, and both an agreement rate and disagree rate between 40%% and 60%%).

subContents.title: ### Automation (4 statements)
subContents.text: This topic included 2 subtopics, comprising a total of 4 statements.

subContents.title: #### Robotics and Automation (3 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had moderately low alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
* **Robotics and Automation in the Workforce**: The statements discuss the increasing presence of robotics and automation, particularly in industries with unskilled or low-skilled workers.
* **Impact of Minimum Wage on Automation**:  The statements suggest a link between minimum wage increases and the adoption of robotics and automation.
* **Unionization of Automated Workers**: One statement proposes the potential unionization of robotic workers.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a point of common ground (at least 20 votes, and at least 70% agreement).

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a significant difference of opinion (at least 20 votes, and both an agreement rate and disagree rate between 40%% and 60%%).

subContents.title: #### Impact on Unskilled Labor (3 statements)
subContents.text: This subtopic had moderately low alignment compared to the other subtopics.

subContents.title: Prominent themes were:
subContents.text:
* **Automation of Unskilled Labor**: The statements suggest that increasing minimum wage will accelerate the adoption of robotics and automation in industries currently relying on unskilled or low-skilled workers.
* **Decreased Demand for Human Workers**:  One statement anticipates a decline in the need for human workers as automation increases, potentially necessitating a universal basic income.
* **Unionization of Automated Labor**: One statement proposes that the rise of automation may lead to the unionization of robotic workers.

subContents.title: Common ground:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a point of common ground (at least 20 votes, and at least 70% agreement).

subContents.title: Differences of opinion:
subContents.text: No statements met the thresholds necessary to be considered as a significant difference of opinion (at least 20 votes, and both an agreement rate and disagree rate between 40%% and 60%%).

comments.text: Businesses, small or large, shouldn't be able to pay workers anything below a livable wage. Why should we subsidize businesses that depend on inadequate wages? If a business's product is good, then this shouldn't be a challenge.
It's just going to speed up the adoption of robotics in industries with unskilled or low-skilled workers.

While the arguments for the raise in the minimum wage law have been trumpeted as being “anti corporate greed”, those larger companies are, ironically, the most able to pay for the increase in wages. This will hurt small businesses the most, and I don’t think the law’s provisions do enough to accommodate this.
I imagine new businesses opening will run counter operations where guests grab their own silverware and bus their own tables.

At the very least, customers across the board are going to have to pay more to accommodate the new wage. Some people will be okay with that but I worry that customers will start spending less and going out less as they adjust to higher prices.

There seems to be a fallacy that instead of lining our richie-rich pockets, business owners will simply break off a little more for their employees. I’m an owner of a small business, and I barely get paid $15 an hour.
This will lead to robots.

I don't think it's a bad thing but for smaller businesses, only the super strong will survive. It will mean that only owners who are willing and able to work every day at their own businesses to reduce labor costs will survive.
During the campaign, I found out that 75% of minimum-wage workers are 20 or older. I think it’s the right thing to do to bring higher incomes to this group of people.
Paying $15/hour to tens of millions of workers around the country will increase the amount they and their families can spend on goods and services, which would provide a huge boost to the economy.
I think it is unlikely that companies will raise prices, as they still have to remain competitive in the market. I think it is more likely that companies will have less profits and I’m ok with that.
Given inflation, unless workers fight they are continually being pushed down. I think we’ll need to revisit these laws again and again to make sure the economy is working for poor families.

It’s called a ‘living wage’ for a reason - there shouldn’t be a debate about the ethics of the law. Anyone who has done the math knows that it’s impossible to pay rent and bills on the present minimum wage.
Good move. Will boost econy here
Something needs to be done to address income inequality and this is a good if imperfect start
One step towards a world where a basic minimum income will be the way developed nations must function as the need for human workers collapses vs populace that "needs a job."
This is something that will impact SMB who cannot afford paying 15$/hour wage
It's so high that it will definitely cost some needy people their jobs.
This is cool! I say hike it up to $20
This will cause small businesses to go out of business.
I agree. The small business will need to make poverty fashionable
$15 min wage will lead to inflation. Higher income population is penalized for this reason and therefore I don't think it is fair.
Guaranteed minimum income! Remove all the specific programs!
Minimum wage will not just lead to robots. Minimum wage will lead to unionized robots. And that's a good thing.
Higher wages makes it super hard for small businesses to survive.  In effect, mom and pop coffee shops with disappear.
the minimum wage should $25 per hour
Not sure I believe any of this...
Reactionary liberal trash. Doesn't solve the problem. It's a systemic problem and this solution is like a band aid on a broken leg.
Hello.
This is a game changer. The myriad of unintended consequences it too complex to really understand; even for restaurant veterans.
I think there are better ways to implement this. For instance, what about subsidies
First piece of spam on polis!  Buy products now!
Awesome!
